metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of soil moisture profile observations in the Yingke oasis and Huazhaizi desert steppe foci experimental areas
metadata.description:
The dataset of soil moisture profile (0cm, 20cm, 40cm and 1m) observations was obtained by TDR (with the probe 12cm and 20cm) in the Yingke oasis and Huazhaizi desert steppe foci experimental areas. Observation items included:
     (1) Soil moisture synchronizing with TM in Yingke oasis No. 1, 4 and 5 maize plots on May 20, 2008.
     (2) Soil moisture synchronizing with ASTER and MODIS in Yingke oasis foci experimental areas on May 28, 2008.
     (3) Soil moisture synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) in Yingke oasis foci experimental areas on May 30, 2008.
     (4) Soil moisture synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) in A'rou grassland on May 31, 2008.
     (5) Soil moisture synchronizing with OMIS-II in Yingke oasis foci experimental areas on Jun. 4, 2008.
     (6) Soil moisture synchronizing with OMIS-II in Yingke oasis maize field on Jun. 16, 2008.
     (7) Soil moisture by TDR and the cutting ring, synchronizing with ASAR in Yingke oasis maize field and wheat field on Jun. 19, 2008.
     (8) Soil moisture synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) in Yingke oasis foci experimental areas on Jun. 29, 2008.
     (9) Soil moisture synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) and TM in Yingke oasis foci experimental areas on Jul. 7, 2008.
     (10) Soil moisture synchronizing with WiDAS (Wide-angle Infrared Dual-mode line/area Array Scanner) in Yingke oasis foci experimental areas on Jul. 11, 2008.

background: Soil moisture is a variable that plays a leading role in surface water and energy balance. The traditional point measurements can just provide a soil moisture distribution in a limited area. The hydrologic models can simulate the soil moisture variation in large spatial and temporal scales. However, the uncertainty in initial model state, model physical parameters, meteorological forcing variables and model equations brings much error in the soil moisture estimation. Many researchers suggested that the most promising approach for estimating soil moisture is the integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data and a hydrologic model (Kostove and Jackson, 1993). Many researches have been carried out on optimizing a computational model through minimizing the difference between the observation and model simulation results by the re-parameterization (Jarlan et al., 2005; Yang et al., 2009) or re-initialization (Heathman et al., 2003; Huang et al., 2008) of the computational model separately. The re-parameterization approach can improve the model state variables by adjusting uncertain parameters. Since some parameters can hardly be obtained by field measurements, they are often estimated from the experiences or references, which brings much uncertainty to the model parameters. The re-initialization approach does not attribute the simulation errors to the uncertainties of the initial conditions, model parameters or model physical equations. It can adjust the state variables directly and it adopts the updated state variables as the initial field to re-initialize the model. The most effective and popular re-initialization approach is Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF).
research objective: This research developed a one-dimensional soil moisture assimilation scheme based on the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA). In this research, the assimilation scheme combined the EnKF and GA as the assimilation algorithm and it could calibrate the model parameters and model initial state synthetically. This paper proposes a one-dimensional soil moisture assimilation scheme combining the EnKF and GA, which has been illuminated by the assimilation experiment carried out in the Heihe River Basin in Northwest China in 2008.
challenges: There is much uncertainty in the assimilation process, which affects the assimilation results. There is much uncertainty in the model initial state and model parameters in the hydrologic modeling, which brings much error to the soil moisture simulation. It is difficult to develop the adjoint model for the original one to evaluate the derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables, which are composed of state variables and model parameters to be estimated. It is complicated to develop the adjoint model in practice, which posed many limitations to its application (Qin et al., 2007).
methods: In this assimilation scheme, the soil moisture was taken as the combination point of the hydrologic model and the backscattering model. The DHSVM was coupled with a semi-empirical backscattering model (Oh) to simulate backscattering coefficients. When the ASAR data were available, a cost function was set up based on the gap between the backscattering coefficients from ASAR observation and the backscattering coefficients from the simulations. Then the EnKF was used to optimize the state variables. If the cost function was higher than twice the ASAR observation noises, the simulation was treated as unacceptable. Then the cost function was minimized by the GA approach. The sensitive parameters of the DHSVM were re-parameterized. The simulations were divided into acceptable and unacceptable cases. The EnKF and GA were used to re-initialize and re-parameterize the simulation process. The assimilation experiment was carried out in the Heihe River Basin, Northwest China.
dataset: The Heihe River Basin, located in the arid area of Northwest China, is the second largest inland river basin, with an area of 116 000 km2 and an average annual precipitation of 108 mm. The ASAR images were used as observation data. ASAR images were acquired for several dates and different polarizations with incidence angles between 10º and 60º, operating in C band. The spatial resolution of ASAR is about 12.5 m × 12.5 m. The spatial resolution of the DHSVM simulation was 30 m, so the spatial resolution of ASAR was resampled into 30 m by the bilinear interpolation method.
findings: The results obtained indicate that this assimilation scheme is practical and it can improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation significantly. The result shows that the model estimate of surface soil moisture was improved by being assimilated with the ASAR data. Additionally, the data assimilation improves the DHSVM model outputs which are more close to the actual values.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure soil moisture profiles in arid regions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used to measure soil moisture profiles involves using ring knife and TDR instruments to measure soil moisture at depths of 0 cm, 20 cm, 40 cm, and 1 m in desert and orchard areas. The method includes synchronous measurements with remote sensing data like TM, ASTER, and MODIS.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using hydrologic models for soil moisture estimation?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in using hydrologic models for soil moisture estimation is the uncertainty in the initial model state, model physical parameters, meteorological forcing variables, and model equations, which can introduce significant errors in soil moisture estimation.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used for soil moisture assimilation experiments in a river basin?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used for soil moisture assimilation experiments is the ASAR images acquired for several dates and different polarizations, with incidence angles between 10º and 60º, operating in C band. These images were used as observation data in the Heihe River Basin, and their spatial resolution was resampled to match the DHSVM simulation spatial resolution.

Feature Specification.Answer: TDR probes of different lengths (12cm and 20cm), ring knives, various depths (0cm, 20cm, 40cm, 1m), deserts, orchards, synchronized with satellite overpasses, airborne remote sensing flights, wet and dry weight percentages, volumetric percentages

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) in soil moisture data assimilation?
Definition.Answer: The Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) is significant in soil moisture data assimilation as it helps to adjust the state variables directly by re-initializing the model, thereby improving the accuracy of soil moisture estimation. It is a popular re-initialization approach that does not attribute simulation errors to the uncertainties of the initial conditions, model parameters, or model physical equations.

Definition.Question: How does the integration of remote sensing data with hydrologic models enhance soil moisture estimation?
Definition.Answer: Integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models enhances soil moisture estimation by providing a means to minimize the difference between observation and model simulation results. This integration allows for the re-parameterization or re-initialization of the computational model, thus improving the accuracy of soil moisture estimates and addressing uncertainties in model parameters and initial states.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with developing an adjoint model for evaluating derivatives of cost functions in hydrologic modeling?
Definition.Answer: The challenges associated with developing an adjoint model for evaluating derivatives of cost functions in hydrologic modeling include the complexity of creating the adjoint model in practice. This complexity poses limitations to its application, as it is difficult to develop the model to evaluate the derivatives with respect to control variables, which comprise state variables and model parameters to be estimated.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of TDR probes for soil moisture measurement in oasis and desert regions compare to the use of remote sensing techniques like ASAR for large spatial scale observations?
Comparison.Answer: TDR probes are used for direct soil moisture measurements at specific depths and locations, providing localized data, whereas ASAR remote sensing techniques allow for broader spatial coverage and integration with hydrologic models, helping to assess soil moisture over larger areas.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do challenges in developing adjoint models for hydrologic modeling compare to uncertainties encountered in model parameter estimation for soil moisture simulations?
Comparison.Answer: Adjoint model development is complex and limits practical application due to difficulties in evaluating derivatives of the cost function, while uncertainties in model parameter estimation arise from relying on experiential or reference-based parameter values, both contributing to errors in soil moisture simulation.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data with hydrologic models enhance the accuracy of soil moisture estimation in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data with hydrologic models allows for the minimization of discrepancies between observed and simulated soil moisture values. This approach can address uncertainties in initial model states, model parameters, and meteorological forcing variables. By employing methods such as re-parameterization and re-initialization, the model's state variables can be adjusted to improve accuracy, as demonstrated in practices like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) combined with Genetic Algorithm (GA).

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are associated with the development of computational models for soil moisture estimation, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in developing computational models for soil moisture estimation include uncertainties in the initial model state, model parameters, and meteorological forcing variables, which can lead to significant errors. Additionally, creating an adjoint model to evaluate derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables is complex. These challenges can be addressed by using approaches like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) that allow for re-parameterization and re-initialization, thus improving the model's state variables and accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How do the spatial and temporal resolutions of remote sensing data affect the evaluation of soil moisture distribution, and what methods can be employed to reconcile differences in resolution?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial and temporal resolutions of remote sensing data are critical in evaluating soil moisture distribution, as traditional point measurements provide limited area coverage. In the context of the Heihe River Basin, ASAR images with a spatial resolution of 12.5 m × 12.5 m were resampled to match the 30 m resolution of the DHSVM simulation using bilinear interpolation. Such resampling methods reconcile differences in resolution, allowing for more accurate assimilation of remote sensing data into hydrologic models, thereby enhancing soil moisture estimation accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the main factors that contribute to uncertainties in soil moisture estimation when integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The main factors contributing to uncertainties in soil moisture estimation include the uncertainty in the initial model state, model physical parameters, meteorological forcing variables, and model equations. These uncertainties can lead to errors in the simulation of soil moisture.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data and hydrologic models considered a promising approach for estimating soil moisture?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The integration of remote sensing surface soil moisture data and hydrologic models is considered promising because it allows for the optimization of computational models by minimizing the difference between observation and simulation results. This approach can improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation by addressing uncertainties in model parameters and initial states.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges arise in developing an assimilation scheme for soil moisture that combines the Ensemble Kalman Filter and Genetic Algorithm?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in developing such an assimilation scheme include managing the uncertainty in the assimilation process, the complexity of developing an adjoint model to evaluate derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables, and the practical limitations posed by these complexities. These challenges can affect the effectiveness and application of the assimilation scheme.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of integrating remote sensing surface soil moisture data with hydrologic models for soil moisture estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating remote sensing surface soil moisture data with hydrologic models can significantly improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation by reducing uncertainties in the model's initial state, parameters, and equations. It allows for a more comprehensive simulation of soil moisture variations across large spatial and temporal scales.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the outcomes of using different remote sensing data, such as ASAR images, in the assimilation experiment for soil moisture estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using ASAR images in the assimilation experiment can enhance the practicality and accuracy of soil moisture estimation. The data assimilation process incorporating ASAR images helps improve the model's output, making it more aligned with actual soil moisture conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind integrating remote sensing soil moisture data with hydrologic models in the context of soil moisture estimation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration aims to improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimation by addressing uncertainties in initial model state, model parameters, and meteorological forcing variables, which are challenges in traditional soil moisture estimation methods.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use various remote sensing instruments, such as ASAR and WiDAS, for soil moisture data collection in different environmental settings?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using various remote sensing instruments provides comprehensive coverage and allows synchronization with ground measurements, enabling better calibration of soil moisture models and improving the accuracy of data collection across different environmental settings.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of re-parameterization and re-initialization in hydrologic modeling for soil moisture data assimilation?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Re-parameterization and re-initialization are significant as they help minimize the differences between observation and model simulation results, thereby enhancing model accuracy by adjusting parameters and state variables to address uncertainties in the hydrologic modeling process.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are required to synchronize soil moisture measurements with satellite overpasses in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In the observed field, synchronization with satellite overpasses involved measuring soil moisture at specific depths on designated dates coinciding with satellite or airborne sensors like TM, ASTER, MODIS, and WiDAS. This included excavation to create soil profiles and using TDR probes of different lengths to measure moisture at various depths, ensuring data alignment with remote sensing observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can traditional soil moisture measurement methods be integrated with remote sensing to improve data accuracy in desert and oasis environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: In this context, traditional methods such as using ring knives and TDR probes are combined with remote sensing data, like ASAR images, to calibrate and validate hydrologic models. The integration is achieved by setting up cost functions based on discrepancies between observed and simulated backscattering coefficients, which are minimized using algorithms like the Ensemble Kalman Filter and Genetic Algorithm.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to handle uncertainties in soil moisture simulation models for arid regions, and how are these uncertainties addressed to enhance model reliability?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Uncertainties in soil moisture simulations are addressed by re-parameterizing models using ensemble methods like the Ensemble Kalman Filter, which adjusts state variables in response to observed discrepancies. This approach is complemented by employing Genetic Algorithms to optimize model parameters, thus refining simulation accuracy by minimizing errors arising from initial model states and parameters.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable accurate soil moisture profiling in varied topographies like oases and deserts?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection methods include using ring knives and TDR probes to measure soil moisture at various depths (0 cm, 20 cm, 40 cm, and 1 m) in locations like deserts and orchards. The TDR probes come in different lengths, such as 12 cm and 20 cm, to measure soil moisture in various soil types, including bare soil and soil under crop residues.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of remote sensing technology enhance soil moisture data collection in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of remote sensing technology, such as using ASAR data coupled with hydrologic models, enables enhanced soil moisture data collection by providing spatially extensive and temporally efficient observations. This helps in overcoming the limitations of traditional point measurements and improves the soil moisture estimation by assimilating remote sensing data with model simulations.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have facilitated synchronous ground and aerial soil moisture measurements?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the use of airborne infrared scanners like WiDAS and imaging spectrometers like OMIS-II have facilitated synchronous ground and aerial soil moisture measurements. These instruments allow for the acquisition of detailed surface data that can be synchronized with satellite overpasses and other aerial observations to achieve comprehensive soil moisture profiling.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be significant uncertainty in soil moisture estimation when using remote sensing data in conjunction with hydrologic models?
Expectation.Answer: There is much uncertainty in the model initial state and model parameters in the hydrologic modeling, which brings much error to the soil moisture simulation. Additionally, the uncertainty in meteorological forcing variables and model equations contributes to inaccuracies in soil moisture estimation.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when attempting to integrate remote sensing data with hydrologic models for soil moisture monitoring?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of remote sensing data with hydrologic models poses challenges, such as the difficulty in developing the adjoint model to evaluate derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables, which are composed of state variables and model parameters to be estimated. This complexity limits the practical application of such integration.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional point measurements of soil moisture be insufficient for large-scale hydrological studies?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional point measurements can only provide soil moisture distribution in a limited area, whereas large-scale hydrological studies require understanding soil moisture variation across extensive spatial and temporal scales. This limitation necessitates the use of remote sensing data and hydrologic models to achieve comprehensive soil moisture monitoring.

Judgmental.Question: How effective is the integration of remote sensing surface data and hydrologic models in addressing the uncertainties present in soil moisture estimation?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration is considered promising as it allows for minimizing differences between observations and model simulations. The use of approaches like re-parameterization and re-initialization, specifically using methods like the Ensemble Kalman Filter, can effectively reduce uncertainties from model parameters and initial conditions, thus improving soil moisture estimation.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges faced in developing an assimilation scheme for soil moisture using genetic algorithms, and how can these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: One major challenge is the uncertainty in the assimilation process, including model initial states and parameters, which introduces errors. Developing an adjoint model for evaluating derivatives of the cost function is also complex. Addressing these challenges involves using combinations of algorithms like the Ensemble Kalman Filter and Genetic Algorithm to optimize state variables and re-parameterize sensitive parameters, as demonstrated in the Heihe River Basin study.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why there is uncertainty in soil moisture estimation when integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models.
Assertion.Answer: The uncertainty in soil moisture estimation arises from several factors, including the initial model state, model physical parameters, meteorological forcing variables, and model equations. These uncertainties can lead to errors in hydrologic modeling, which is why integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models requires careful consideration and optimization techniques like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) to improve accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand what challenges are faced when developing a soil moisture assimilation scheme using ASAR data.
Assertion.Answer: One of the challenges is the uncertainty in the assimilation process, which affects the results. There are also difficulties in developing the adjoint model for evaluating derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables. This complexity limits practical applications, requiring methods like the Genetic Algorithm (GA) to minimize the cost function and improve model accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the various data collection methods used for measuring soil moisture in arid regions and discuss their advantages and limitations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods used for measuring soil moisture in the specified arid region include the use of ring knife sampling and Time Domain Reflectometry (TDR). In this field, soil profiles are excavated up to 1m depth, and measurements are taken at 0cm, 20cm, 40cm, and 1m. TDR probes of 12cm and 20cm lengths are used to measure soil moisture in different types of soil surfaces such as bare soil, under plastic mulch, and wheat under soil. These methods allow for detailed soil moisture profiling but are limited by their spatial coverage and the need for synchronization with remote sensing data to provide a broader spatial context.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and analyze the main challenges faced in integrating remote sensing data with hydrologic models for soil moisture estimation.
Request/Directive.Answer: In the integration of remote sensing data with hydrologic models for soil moisture estimation, significant challenges include the uncertainty in the initial model state, model parameters, and meteorological forcing variables. These uncertainties lead to errors in soil moisture estimation. Developing an adjoint model to evaluate derivatives of the cost function with respect to control variables is complex, posing limitations to its practical application. Approaches such as re-parameterization and re-initialization using methods like the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) and Genetic Algorithm (GA) are used to address these challenges by optimizing model parameters and state variables.
